00067 /// \brief  A complex data struct.
00068 typedef struct 
00069 { 
00070   double re; //!< The real part.
00071   double im; //!< The imaginary part.
00072 } stComplex;
00073 
00074 /// \brief  The deep level matrix struct. The matrix is either real or complex.
00075 typedef struct
00076 {  
00077   unsigned   nrows;   //!< The number of rows in the matrix.
00078   unsigned   ncols;   //!< The number of columns in the matrix.
00079   BOOL       isReal;  //!< This indicates if is the matrix real or complex.
00080   double     **data;  //!< This is a pointer to an array of double column vectors.
00081   stComplex  **cplx;  //!< Thsi is a pointer to an array of complex column vectors.
00082   char      *comment; //!< This is a comment string (if applicable).
00083 } MTX;
00084

00086 /// \brief  This function must be called first by users of cmatrix!
00087 ///
00088 /// \return TRUE if successful, FALSE otherwise.
00089 BOOL MTX_Initialize_MTXEngine();

00091 
00092 /// \brief  This function is used to set if matrices that are single 
00093 ///         elements (1x1) are treated as scalars for math operations
00094 ///         or whether the regular matrix rules apply. THIS IS ENABLED
00095 ///         BY DEFAULT.
00096 ///
00097 /// \return TRUE if successful, FALSE otherwise.
00098 BOOL MTX_Enable1x1MatricesForTreatmentAsScalars( BOOL enable );

00103 BOOL MTX_isNull( const MTX *M );

00106 /// \brief  Are matrices A & B conformal for multiplication, real * real
00107 ///
00108 /// \return TRUE if successful, FALSE otherwise.
00109 BOOL MTX_isConformalForMultiplication( const MTX *A, const MTX *B );

00112 ///
00113 /// \return TRUE if successful, FALSE otherwise.

00126 /// \brief  Initialize a MTX matrix struct to appropriate zero values. This must always be called for proper operation!
00127 /// \code
00128 /// MTX matrix;
00129 /// MTX_Init( &matrix );
00130 /// \endcode
00131 ///
00132 /// \return TRUE if successful, FALSE otherwise.
00133 BOOL MTX_Init( MTX *M );

00212 
00213 /// \brief  If M is a real matrix, Magnitude is a copy.
00214 /// If M is a complex matrix, Magnitude is a real matrix = sqrt( re*re + im*im ).
00215 ///
00216 /// \return TRUE if successful, FALSE otherwise.
00217 BOOL MTX_Magnitude( const MTX *M, MTX *Magnitude );
00218 
00219 /// \brief  If M is a real matrix, Phase is a zero matrix.
00220 /// If M is a complex matrix, Phase is a real matrix = atan2(im,re).
00221 ///
00222 /// \return TRUE if successful, FALSE otherwise.
00223 BOOL MTX_Phase( const MTX *M, MTX *Phase );
00224 
00225 /// \brief  If M is a real matrix, nothing is done.
00226 /// If M is a complex matrix, the conjugate is set.
00227 ///
00228 /// \return TRUE if successful, FALSE otherwise.
00229 BOOL MTX_Conjugate( MTX *M );

00232 ///

00376 /// \brief  Round the matrix elements to the specified precision.\n
00377 /// e.g. precision = 0    1.8    -> 2\n
00378 /// e.g. precision = 1,   1.45   -> 1.5\n
00379 /// e.g. precision = 2    1.456  -> 1.46\n
00380 /// e.g. precision = 3,   1.4566 -> 1.457\n
00381 ///
00382 /// \return TRUE if successful, FALSE otherwise.
00383 BOOL MTX_Round( MTX *M, const unsigned precision );                             
00384 
00385 /// \brief  Round the matrix elements to the nearest integers towards minus infinity.
00386 ///
00387 /// \return TRUE if successful, FALSE otherwise.
00388 BOOL MTX_Floor( MTX *M );
00389 
00390 /// \brief  Round the matrix elements to the nearest integers towards infinity.
00391 ///
00392 /// \return TRUE if successful, FALSE otherwise.
00393 BOOL MTX_Ceil( MTX *M );
00394

00396 ///
00397 /// \return TRUE if successful, FALSE otherwise.
00398 BOOL MTX_Fix( MTX *M );

00450 /// \brief  Convert a value to a string with the specified width and precision.
00451 /// analogous to sprintf( ValueBuffer, "%'blank''-'width.precision'g'", value );
00452 ///
00453 /// \return TRUE if successful, FALSE otherwise.
00454 BOOL MTX_ValueToString( 
00455   const double value,             //!< The double value to output.
00456   const unsigned width,           //!< The width of the field.
00457   const unsigned precision,       //!< The precision, %g style.
00458   const BOOL isReal,              //!< The the value the real part or the imaginary part.
00459   const BOOL alignLeft,           //!< Align the output left (for real data only).
00460   char *ValueBuffer,              //!< The output buffer.
00461   const unsigned ValueBufferSize  //!< The size of the output buffer.
00462   );
00463 
00464 /// \brief  Print the matrix to a file with specifed width and precision.
00465 /// MTX_PrintAutoWidth is recommended over this function, "%'blank''-'width.precision'g'".
00466 ///
00467 /// \return TRUE if successful, FALSE otherwise.
00468 BOOL MTX_Print( const MTX *M, const char *path, const unsigned width, const unsigned precision, const BOOL append );
00469 
00470 /// \brief  Print the matrix to a buffer of maxlength with specifed width and precision.
00471 /// MTX_PrintAutoWidth is recommended over this function, "%'blank''-'width.precision'g'".
00472 ///
00473 /// \return TRUE if successful, FALSE otherwise.
00474 BOOL MTX_Print_ToBuffer( const MTX *M, char *buffer, const unsigned maxlength, const unsigned width, const unsigned precision );
00475

00477 /// and the specified precision, uses "%'blank''-'autowidth.precision'g'".
00478 ///
00479 /// \return TRUE if successful, FALSE otherwise.
00480 BOOL MTX_PrintAutoWidth( const MTX *M, const char *path, const unsigned precision, const BOOL append );
00481

00487

00493 
00494 /// \brief  Print the matrix to a file with specifed precision and delimiter.

00513 // Math operations
00514 
00515 /// \brief  Adds a scalar double to matrix M, ie: M += 5.
00516 ///
00517 /// \return TRUE if successful, FALSE otherwise.
00518 BOOL MTX_Add_Scalar( MTX *M, const double scalar );
00519 
00520 /// \brief  Adds a scalar complex to matrix M, ie: M += (5 + 3i).
00521 ///
00522 /// \return TRUE if successful, FALSE otherwise.
00523 BOOL MTX_Add_ScalarComplex( MTX *M, const double re, const double im );
00524 
00525 /// \brief  Subtracts a scalar double from matrix M, ie: M -= 5.
00526 ///
00527 /// \return TRUE if successful, FALSE otherwise.
00528 BOOL MTX_Subtract_Scalar( MTX *M, const double scalar );
00529 
00530 /// \brief  Subtracts a scaler complex from matrix M, ie: M -= (5+3i).
00531 ///
00532 /// \return TRUE if successful, FALSE otherwise.
00533 BOOL MTX_Subtract_ScalarComplex( MTX *M, const double re, const double im );
00534 
00535 /// \brief  Multiply M with a double scalar inplace, ie: M *= 5.
00536 ///
00537 /// \return TRUE if successful, FALSE otherwise.
00538 BOOL MTX_Multiply_Scalar( MTX *M, const double scalar );
00539 
00540 /// \brief  Multiply M with a complex scalar inplace, ie: M *= (5+3i).
00541 ///
00542 /// \return TRUE if successful, FALSE otherwise.
00543 BOOL MTX_Multiply_ScalarComplex( MTX *M, const double re, const double im );
00544 
00545 /// \brief  Divide M by scaler double inplace, ie: M /= 5.
00546 ///
00547 /// \return TRUE if successful, FALSE otherwise.
00548 BOOL MTX_Divide_Scalar( MTX *M, const double scalar );
00549 
00550 /// \brief  Divide M by scaler complex inplace, ie: M /= (5+3i).
00551 ///
00552 /// \return TRUE if successful, FALSE otherwise.
00553 BOOL MTX_Divide_ScalarComplex( MTX *M, const double re, const double im );
00554 
00555 
00556 /// \brief  Computes the absolute value of each element in the matrix.
00557 ///
00558 /// \return TRUE if successful, FALSE otherwise.
00559 BOOL MTX_Abs( MTX *M );
00560 
00561 /// \brief  Computes the value^2 of each element in the matrix.
00562 ///
00563 /// \return TRUE if successful, FALSE otherwise.
00564 BOOL MTX_Sqr( MTX *M );
00565 
00566 /// \brief  Computes the sqrt(value) of each element in the matrix.
00567 /// A real matrix is converted to complex if any elements are negative.
00568 /// e.g. sqrt(-1) = -i.
00569 ///
00570 /// \return TRUE if successful, FALSE otherwise.
00571 BOOL MTX_Sqrt( MTX *M );
00572 
00573 /// \brief  If real, computes the exp(value) of each element in the matrix.
00574 /// If complex, computes exp(M) = exp(real)*(cos(imag)+i*sin(imag)).
00575 ///
00576 /// \return TRUE if successful, FALSE otherwise.
00577 BOOL MTX_Exp( MTX *M );
00578 
00579 /// \brief  Computes the natural logarithm, ln(value) of each element in the matrix.
00580 ///
00581 /// \return TRUE if successful, FALSE otherwise.
00582 BOOL MTX_Ln( MTX *M );
00583 
00584 /// \brief  Raise all elements in src^(power_re + power_im*i) and store in dst.
00585 /// If power is just real, power_im = 0.0.
00586 ///
00587 /// \return TRUE if successful, FALSE otherwise.
00588 BOOL MTX_Pow( const MTX *src, MTX *dst, const double power_re, const double power_im );
00589 
00590 /// \brief  Raise all elements in src^(power_re + power_im*i).
00591 /// If power is just real, power_im = 0.0.
00592 ///
00593 /// \return TRUE if successful, FALSE otherwise.
00594 BOOL MTX_PowInplace( MTX *src, const double power_re, const double power_im );
00595

00674 /// \brief  Difference and approximate derivative.

00677 ///
00678 /// \return TRUE if successful, FALSE otherwise.

00995 
00996 /// \brief  Computes the sample skewness value for the specified row.
00997 /// The skewness is the third central moment divided by the cube of the standard deviation.
00998 /// If the matrix is real, only the real value, re is set, im = 0. 
00999 /// If the matrix is complex, both re and im are set.
01000 ///
01001 /// \return TRUE if successful, FALSE otherwise.
01002 BOOL MTX_RowSkewness( const MTX *M, const unsigned row, double *re, double* im );
01003 
01004 /// \brief  Computes the sample skewness value for the matrix.
01005 /// The skewness is the third central moment divided by the cube of the standard deviation.
01006 /// If the matrix is real, only the real value, re is set, im = 0. 
01007 /// If the matrix is complex, both re and im are set.

01013 
01014 /// \brief  Computes the sample kurtosis value for the specified column.
01015 /// The kurtosis is the fourth central moment divided by fourth power of the standard deviation.
01016 /// If the matrix is real, only the real value, re is set, im = 0. 
01017 /// If the matrix is complex, both re and im are set.
01018 /// To adjust the computed kurtosis value for bias, subtract 3 from the real component.
01019 /// Reference: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kurtosis.
01020 /// Reference: http://mathworld.wolfram.com/Kurtosis.html (kurtosis proper is computed).
01021 /// g_2 = \frac{m_4}{m_{2}^2} = \frac{n\,\sum_{i=1}^n (x_i - \overline{x})^4}{\left(\sum_{i=1}^n (x_i - \overline{x})^2\right)^2}.
01022 ///
01023 /// \return TRUE if successful, FALSE otherwise.
01024 BOOL MTX_ColumnKurtosis( const MTX *M, const unsigned col, double *re, double *im );
01025 
01026 /// \brief  Computes the sample kurtosis value for the specified row.
01027 /// The kurtosis is the fourth central moment divided by fourth power of the standard deviation.
01028 /// If the matrix is real, only the real value, re is set, im = 0. 
01029 /// If the matrix is complex, both re and im are set.
01030 /// To adjust the computed kurtosis value for bias, subtract 3 from the real component.
01031 /// Reference: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kurtosis.
01032 /// Reference: http://mathworld.wolfram.com/Kurtosis.html (kurtosis proper is computed).
01033 /// g_2 = \frac{m_4}{m_{2}^2} = \frac{n\,\sum_{i=1}^n (x_i - \overline{x})^4}{\left(\sum_{i=1}^n (x_i - \overline{x})^2\right)^2}.
01034 ///
01035 /// \return TRUE if successful, FALSE otherwise.
01036 BOOL MTX_RowKurtosis( const MTX *M, const unsigned row, double *re, double *im );
01037 
01038 
01039 /// \brief  Computes the sample kurtosis value for the matrix.
01040 /// The kurtosis is the fourth central moment divided by fourth power of the standard deviation.
01041 /// If the matrix is real, only the real value, re is set, im = 0. 
01042 /// If the matrix is complex, both re and im are set.
01043 /// To adjust the computed kurtosis value for bias, subtract 3 from the real component.
01044 /// Reference: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kurtosis.
01045 /// Reference: http://mathworld.wolfram.com/Kurtosis.html (kurtosis proper is computed).
01046 /// g_2 = \frac{m_4}{m_{2}^2} = \frac{n\,\sum_{i=1}^n (x_i - \overline{x})^4}{\left(\sum_{i=1}^n (x_i - \overline{x})^2\right)^2}.
01047 ///
01048 /// \return TRUE if successful, FALSE otherwise.
01049 BOOL MTX_Kurtosis( const MTX *M, double *re, double *im );
01050

01145 
01146 /// \brief  Alter the matrix, M, so that its data is within the startTime to the startTime+duration
01147 /// and compensate for any rollovers in the time system (e.g. GPS time in seconds rolls over
01148 /// at 604800.0 s). This function assumes that time is one of the matrix columns and requires
01149 /// this index, the timeColumn.
01150 ///
01151 /// \return TRUE if successful, FALSE otherwise.
01152 BOOL MTX_TimeWindow( 
01153   MTX* M,                     //!< Matrix to be altered
01154   const unsigned timeColumn,   //!< The column containing time
01155   const double startTime,      //!< The specified start time (inclusive)
01156   const double duration,       //!< The duration to include
01157   const double rolloverTime ); //!< The potential time at which system time rolls over
01158 
01159 /// \brief  Alter the matrix, M, so that its data is within [startTime endTime].
01160 /// This function assumes that time is one of the matrix columns and requires
01161 /// this index, the timeColumn.
01162 ///
01163 /// \return TRUE if successful, FALSE otherwise.
01164 BOOL MTX_TimeLimit( 
01165   MTX* M,                     //!< Matrix to be altered
01166   const unsigned timeColumn,   //!< The column containing time
01167   const double startTime,      //!< The specified start time (inclusive)
01168   const double endTime );      //!< The duration to include
01169   
01170 
01171 /// \brief  This function matches matrices in time with specified precision
01172 /// where time is a column of each matrix. This function also
01173 /// allows time to rollover at a specified interval.
01174 ///
01175 ///    precision 0 = match to whole number \n
01176 ///    precision 1 = match to nearest 0.1 \n
01177 ///    precision 2 = match to nearest 0.01 \n
01178 ///    etc. \n
01179 /// rolloverTime examples \n
01180 ///     GPS time of week (s): rolloverTime= 604800.0 \n
01181 ///     hours               : rolloverTime = 24.0 \n
01182 ///     minutes             : rolloverTime = 60.0 \n
01183 ///
01184 /// The time data must be non-decreasing but the time may rollover
01185 /// by the specified amount. 
01186 /// e.g. rolloverTime = 60.0 \n
01187 ///      0,1,2,3,4,...59,60,1,2,5,10,60,1,2,3... \n
01188 ///
01189 /// \return TRUE if successful, FALSE otherwise.
01190 BOOL MTX_TimeMatch( 
01191   MTX *A,                      //!< The matrix with interpolation times
01192   const unsigned timeColumnA,  //!< The zero based column index for matrix A
01193   MTX *B,                      //!< The matrix to be interpolated
01194   const unsigned timeColumnB,  //!< The zero based column index for matrix B
01195   const unsigned precision,    //!< The rounding precision used for time matching, 0 = whole, 1 = 0.1, 2 = 0.01, etc
01196   const double rolloverTime    //!< The rollover time, e.g. 60 s for minute based timing, 0.0 means rollovers not allowed
01197   );
01198 
01199 
01200 
01201 /// \brief  This function interpolates Matrix B values by the times defined 
01202 /// in the column in Matrix A. Time must be increasing but times can 
01203 /// rollover with the specified rolloverTime.
01204 ///
01205 /// This function returns A and B with the same number of rows and 
01206 /// time aligned time columns.
01207 ///
01208 /// \return TRUE if successful, FALSE otherwise.
01209 BOOL MTX_Interpolate( 
01210   MTX *A,                     //!< The matrix with interpolation times
01211   const unsigned timeColumnA, //!< The zero based column index for matrix A
01212   MTX *B,                     //!< The matrix to be interpolated
01213   const unsigned timeColumnB, //!< The zero based column index for matrix B
01214   const double maxInterpolationInterval, //!< The largest interpolation interval allowed
01215   const double rolloverTime   //!< The rollover time, e.g. 60 s for minute based timing, 0.0 means rollovers not allowed
01216   );
01217

01220 /// \brief  Compute the inplace inverse of the matrix.
01221 ///         Uses fast closed form solutions for:
01222 ///         Only for: 1x1, 2x2, 3x3
01223 ///
01224 /// If the matrix is singular, the original matrix is unchanged.
01225 ///
01226 /// \return TRUE if successful, FALSE if empty or has dimensions larger
01227 ///         than 3x3, false if singular or not square
01228 BOOL MTX_InvertInPlaceClosedForm( MTX *M );
01229 
01230 
01231 
01232 /// \brief  Compute the inplace inverse of a postive definite matrix.
01233 ///
01234 /// The matrix is first tested to determine if it is a symmetric 
01235 /// positive-definite matrix. If so, Cholesky decomposition is used
01236 /// to facilitate the inversion of a lower triangular matrix. If the
01237 /// matrix is not symmetric and positive-definite robust inversion
01238 /// using gaussing elimination is attempted.
01239 ///
01240 /// 3x3 matrices or smaller dimensions are computed using 
01241 /// MTX_InvertInPlaceClosedForm.
01242 /// 
01243 /// If the matrix is singular, the original matrix is unchanged.
01244 ///
01245 /// \return TRUE if successful, FALSE otherwise.
01246 BOOL MTX_InvertInPlace( MTX *M  );
01247 
01248 
01249 /// \brief  Perfroms an inplace inverse using Gaussian Elimination methods.
01250 ///
01251 /// \return TRUE if successful, FALSE otherwise.
01252 BOOL MTX_InvertInPlaceRobust( MTX *M );

01274 /// \brief  Compute the inplace inverse of a unit lower triangular matrix.
01275 /// An example unit lower triangular matrix is: \n
01276 ///      A = [     1    0    0;          \n
01277 ///               -2    2    0;          \n
01278 ///                4   -3    3 ]; with   \n
01279 /// inv(A) = [     1    0    0;          \n

01281 ///             -1/3  1/2  1/3 ];        \n

01283 /// \return TRUE if successful, FALSE otherwise.

01346 /// \brief  Create a column vector [start:increment:end) beginning at start
01347 /// with step size of increment until less than or equal to end. 
01348 /// Note that arguments must be real scalars. \n
01349 /// e.g. a = 2:2:9   = [2; 4; 6; 8;] \n

01352 /// \return TRUE if successful, FALSE otherwise.

01356 /** \brief  A very efficient method to remove rows and columns from the matrix.
01357 *
01358 * \code 
01359 *  MTX A;
01360 *  unsigned rows[2];
01361 *  unsigned cols[2];
01362 *  MTX_Init(&A);
01363 *  MTX_Calloc( &A, 4, 4 );
01364 *  MTX_Identity( &A );
01365 *  A.data[0][0] = 100.0;
01366 *  A.data[2][1] = 10.0;
01367 *  A.data[1][2] = 20.0;
01368 *  // remove the first row and column and the third row and column.
01369 *  rows[0] = 0;
01370 *  rows[1] = 2;
01371 *  cols[0] = 0;
01372 *  cols[1] = 2;
01373 *  MTX_RemoveRowsAndColumns( &A, 2, (unsigned*)rows, 2 (unsigned*)cols );
01374 *  // A is now a 2x2 identity matrix.
01375 *  /endcode
01376 *
01377 *  \return TRUE if successful, FALSE otherwise.
01378 */
01379 BOOL MTX_RemoveRowsAndColumns( 
01380   MTX *src,        //!< The pointer to the matrix object.
01381   const unsigned nrows,  //!< The number of rows to remove (the length of the rows array).
01382   const unsigned rows[], //!< The array of row indices to remove.
01383   const unsigned ncols,  //!< The number of columns to remove (the length of hte cols array).
01384   const unsigned cols[]
01385   );
